text: how do you pull this together and say
how genomics can help us understand all
of these different ways the environment
plays into cancer I think Eric put it in
a in a very succinct incorrect way at in
his opening remark and that is that all
cancer is the consequence of mutations
in genes all cancer is the consequence
of aberrations in DNA and those can be
mediated by viruses if viruses work
their way into the genome they can be
the consequence of exposure to mutagens
to eat two agents that themselves cause
mutations such as radiation they can be
the result of chance they can be the
result of inheritance of a mutation from
apparent in which case of course all the
cells are affected rather than simply
the cancer cells so there are a wide
variety of different causal mechanisms
but they converge on this one global
mechanism which is changes in the DNA
which is the conceptual basis of why the
Cancer Genome Project works so that
understanding those changes in the DNA
that endpoint is it could lead to the
new treatments as long as we understand
that there are many changes in cancers
that are irrelevant to either the cause
of the progression of cancer it's a
subtle but but critical point I think
and the others will will chime in on
this they're the mutations that are
critical both in the cause of cancer and
in its progression have as one of their
consequences many of them the opening up
of the floodgates for more mutations
they are mutations which in and of
themselves destroy the capacity of the
cell to repair other mutations so a cell
that had formerly when it was a normal
cell been completely able to repair what
went wrong or Costa completely now
becomes completely vulnerable and the
least little thing can cause a mutation
which is one reason we get resistance in
cancer because they are so vulnerable to
additional mutations go ahead put some
numbers on this if you take a tumor and
you sequence its DNA and you compare it
to the DNA of that same person in their
normal cells you might find about one
mutation every million letters so about
3,000 mutations in the genome now in the
in the part of the DNA that encodes the
pro
teams that might be about 30 or 40 or 50
mutations that change proteins but
there's a tremendous variance well of
course we'll get to that some summits
more some less but I'm picking an
average number here but Mary Claire will
correctly point out that there's some
variations find everything but the point
is that most of those changes are random
changes that aren't causing the cancer
so if i look at one person's children
most of those changes aren't informative
but if i look at two people and three
people and 10 people and a thousand
people then i can begin to see that this
gene is getting hit much more often than
by chance or as this is just sort of
chance noise so a Cancer Genome Project
needs much more than one patient needs
many patients but cancer is no rare
disease it's totally possible to look at
enough patients that you can sift out
that noise and see the signal
